description: For clarity, A is the system initiating the query and B is the system sending the responses.  Multiple queries and responses are permitted within single messages.  The responses to a given query may be broken into several separate DSR messages.  A single DSR message may contain responses to more than one QRY

segments.description:
The MSH segment defines the intent, source, destination, and some specifics of the syntax of a message.

Note: If MSH-15 and MSH-16 are omitted (or are both null), the original Acknowledgement Mode rules are used.

fields.name: Field Separator
fields.description: actually the separator between the segment ID and the first real field, MSH-2-encoding characters.  As such it serves as the separator and defines the character to be used as a separator for the rest of the message.  Recommended value is |.

fields.name: Encoding Characters
fields.description: four characters in the following order: the component separator, repetition separator, escape character, and subcomponent separator.  Recommended values are ^~\&.

fields.name: Sending Application
fields.description: available for interface with lower level protocols

fields.name: Sending Facility
fields.description: addresses one of several occurrences of the same application within the sending system.  Absent other considerations, the Medicare Provider ID might be used with an appropriate sub-identifier in the second component.  Entirely site-defined

fields.name: Receiving Application
fields.description: available for interface with lower level protocols

fields.name: Receiving Facility
fields.description: identifies the receiving application among multiple identical instances of the application running on behalf of different organizations.  See comments: sending facility

fields.name: Date / Time Of Message
fields.description: date/time that the sending system created the message.  If the time zone is specified, it will be used throughout the message as the default time zone

fields.name: Security
fields.description: in some applications of HL7 this field will be used to implement security features.  Its use is not yet further specified

fields.name: Message Type
fields.description: first component is the message type edited by table 0076 - message type; second is the trigger event code edited by table 0003 - event type code.  Receiving system uses this field to know the data segments to recognize, and possibly, the application to which to route this message.  For certain queries, which may have more than a single response event type, the second component may, in the response message, vary to indicate the response event type.  See the discussion of the display query variants in Section 2.8.6.1.1.  The second component is not required on response or acknowledgement messages

fields.name: Message Control Id
fields.description: number or other identifier that uniquely identifies the message.  The receiving system echoes this ID back to the sending system in the Message Acknowledgement segment (MSA).

fields.name: Processing Id
fields.description: used to decide whether to process the message as defined in HL7 Application (level 7)  Processing rules.

fields.name: Version Id
fields.description: matched by the receiving system to its own version to be sure the message will be interpreted correctly

fields.name: Sequence Number
fields.description: non-null value in this field implies that the sequence number protocol is in use.  This numeric field incremented by one for each subsequent value

fields.name: Continuation Pointer
fields.description: used to define continuations in application-specific ways

fields.name: Accept Acknowledgement Type
fields.description: defines the conditions under which accept acknowledgements are required to be returned in response to this message.  Required for enhanced acknowledgement mode.  Refer to table 0155 - acknowledgement conditions for valid values

fields.name: Application Acknowledgement Type
fields.description: defines the conditions under which  application  acknowledgements are required to be returned in response to this message.  Required for enhanced acknowledgement mode

fields.name: Country Code
fields.description: defines the country of origin for the message.  It will be used primarily to specify default elements, such as currency denominations.   ISO 3166 provides a list of country codes that may be used.

segments.description: The MSA segment contains information sent while acknowledging another message

fields.name: Acknowledgement Code
fields.description: see message processing rules

fields.name: Message Control Id
fields.description: message control ID of the message sent by the sending system.  It allows the sending system to associate this response with the message for which it is intended

fields.name: Text Message
fields.description: optional text field that further describes an error condition.  This text may be printed in error logs or presented to an end user

fields.name: Expected Sequence Number
fields.description: optional numeric field used in the sequence number protocol

fields.name: Delayed Acknowledgement Type
fields.description: used only as described above, in Section 2.5.2.  Otherwise this field is not used

fields.name: Error Condition
fields.description: CE field allowing the acknowledging system to use a user-defined error code to further specify AR or AE type acknowledgements.  This field is a generalized replacement for MSA-3-text message

fields.name: Identifier
fields.description: Sequence of characters (the code) that uniquely identifies the item being referenced by the <text>.  Different coding schemes will have different elements here.

fields.name: Text
fields.description: Name or description of the item in question.  E.g., myocardial infarction or x-ray impression.  Its data type is string (ST).

fields.name: Name Of Coding System
fields.description: Each coding system will be assigned a unique identifier.  This component will serve to identify the coding scheme being used in the identifier component. The combination of the identifier and name of coding system components will be a unique code for a data item.  For backward compatibility, if this component is absent, it will be taken to mean the CPT-4 with ASTM extensions, i.e., AS4.  Other coding systems that might appear here are ICD-9, ICD-10, SNOMED, etc.  Each system will be given a unique identifying string.  The current ASTM 1238-88  diagnostic/procedure/observation/drug ID/health outcomes coding systems are identified in the tables below.  Others may be added as needed.

fields.name: Alternate Identifier
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the Alternate Text component is absent, and the Alternate Identifier is present, the Alternate Text will be taken to be the same as the Text component.  If the Alternate Coding System component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally defined system

fields.name: Alternate Text
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the Alternate Text component is absent, and the Alternate Identifier is present, the Alternate Text will be taken to be the same as the Text component.  If the Alternate Coding System component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally defined system

fields.name: Name Of Alternate Coding System
fields.description: These three components are defined analogously to the above for the alternate or local coding system.  If the Alternate Text component is absent, and the Alternate Identifier is present, the Alternate Text will be taken to be the same as the Text component.  If the Alternate Coding System component is absent, it will be taken to mean the locally defined system

fields.name: Query Date / Time
fields.description: date the query was generated by the application program

fields.name: Query Format Code
fields.description: refer to table 0106 - query format code for valid codes

fields.name: Query Priority
fields.description: time frame in which the response is expected.  Refer to table 0091 - query priority for valid codes.  Table values and subsequent fields specify time frames for response

fields.name: Query Id
fields.description: unique identifier for the query.  Assigned by the querying application.  Returned intact by the responding application.

fields.name: Deferred Response Type
fields.description: refer to table 0107 - deferred response type for valid entries

fields.name: Deferred Response Date / Time
fields.description: date/time before or after which to send a deferred response.  If not present, the response can be sent when its available

fields.name: Quantity Limited Request
fields.description: maximum length of the response that can be accepted by the requesting system.  Valid responses are numerical values given in the units specified in the second component.  Refer to table 0126 - quantity limited request for valid entries.  Default is LI lines

fields.name: Units
fields.description: The units in which the quantity is expressed.  Field-by-field, default units may be defined within the specifications.  When the observation is measured in the default units, the units need not be transmitted.  If the measure is recorded in units different from the default, the measurement units must be transmitted as the second component.  If the units are ISO+ units, then units should be recorded as lowercase abbreviations as specified in Chapter 7.  If the units are ANSI or local, the units and the source table must be recorded as specified in Chapter 7.  But in these cases the component separator should be replaced by the subcomponent delimiter

fields.name: Who Subject Filter
fields.description: identifies the subject, or who the inquiry is about

fields.name: What Subject Filter
fields.description: describes the kind of information that is required to satisfy the request.  Valid codes define the type of transaction inquiry and may be extended locally during implementation

fields.name: What Department Data Code
fields.description: possible contents include test number, procedure number, drug code, item number, order number, etc.  The contents of this field are determined by the contents of the previous field. This field could contain multiple occurrences separated by repetition delimiters

fields.name: What Data Code Value Qualifier
fields.description: what data code value qualifier.  A window or range to further refine the inquiry.  This field would contain start/stop separated by component separators

fields.name: Query Results Level
fields.description: used to control level of detail in results.  Refer to table 0108 - query results level for valid codes

segments.description: The QRF segment is used with the QRD segment to refine the content of a query further

fields.name: Where Subject Filter
fields.description: identifies the department, system, or subsystem to which the query pertains.  This field may repeat as in LAB~HEMO, etc

fields.name: When Data Start Date / Time
fields.description: data representing dates and times equal or after this value should be included

fields.name: When Data End Date / Time
fields.description: data representing dates and times the same as or before this date should be included

fields.name: What User Qualifier
fields.description: an identifier to further define characteristics of the data of interest

fields.name: Other Qry Subject Filter
fields.description: a filter defined locally for use between two systems.  This filter uses codes and field definitions which have specific meaning only to the applications and/or site involved

fields.name: Which Date / Time Qualifier
fields.description: specifies type of date referred to in QRF-2-when data start date/time and QRF-3-when data end date/time

fields.name: Which Date / Time Status Qualifier
fields.description: specifies status type of objects selected in date range defined by QRF-2-when data start date/time and QRF-3-when data end date/time).

fields.name: Date / Time Selection Qualifier
fields.description: allows specification of certain types of values within the date/time range.

segments.description: The DSP segment is used to contain data that has been preformatted by the sender for display.  The semantic content of the data is lost; the data is simply treated as lines of text.

fields.name: Set Id - Display Data
fields.description: used optionally to number multiple display segments

fields.name: Display Level
fields.description: individual sites or applications may assign numbering to define groups of data elements

fields.name: Data Line
fields.description: contains an actual line as it should be displayed.  As described for the TX data type, highlighting and other special display characteristics may be included

fields.name: Logical Break Point
fields.description: non-null if this line is the last line of a logical break point in the response as defined by the responding system.  See Section 2.8.5 for the discussion of Logical display break points

fields.name: Result Id
fields.description: if the user selects a result ID (defined by DSP-5-logical break point) from the screen display corresponding to a record in which DSP-5-result ID is non-null, the application can initiate a second query (a separate session) to the ancillary with the QRD-10-what department data code filled in with this non-null value (e.g., the ancillary accession number or its equivalent).  The ancillary response will contain the report referenced by this result ID (e.g., accession number).  The ancillary should correlate the result ID with DSP-4-logical break point as follows: If more than one line of text is sent per result, DSP-5-result ID should be only non-null for a DSP segment that contains a non-null DSP-4-logical break point.  This field may be broken into components by local agreement.  A common example might be to include placer order number, filler order number, and universal service identifier.  Whenever such fields are used as components of the result ID, their components will be sent as subcomponents

segments.description: The DSC segment is used in the continuation protocol.

fields.name: Continuation Pointer
fields.description: see description of Continuation Fields in Section 2.8.4.  In an initial query, this field is null.  If the responder returns a value of null or not present, then there is no more data to fulfill any future continuation requests.  For use with continuations of unsolicited messages, see sections 2.7.2 and 2.9.2.  Note that continuation protocols work with both display and record-oriented messages
